longInfo:
Passport required.
- Passports and/or passport replacing documents must be valid
  for at least 6 months from date of arrival. 
Passport Exemptions:
- Holders of emergency or temporary passports.

Visa required, except for Holders of a Persons of Surinamese
Origin (PSA) document.
Visa Issuance:
Visa required, except for Holders of normal, emergency or
temporary passports issued to nationals of French West Indies
traveling as a tourist can obtain a single entry Tourist Card
on arrival at Paramaribo International Airport (PBM), for a
max. stay of 90 days. Fee: between USD 20.- and USD 25.-. 
Minors:
- WARNING! In accordance with European Union (EU) Legislation,
  all minors who are nationals of French West Indies will be
  expected to hold their own passport or National ID Card
  (where applicable) when departing from Bulgaria, Croatia,
  Cyprus, Romania or a Schengen Member State . 
Additional Information:
- Extension of stay available for a max. stay of 6 months for
  visitors of Suriname origin. 
Warning:
- Nationals of French West Indies who have visited Guinea,
  Liberia or Sierra Leone within the last 21 days will be
  refused entry. Exempt are holders of PCR (Polymerase Chain
  Reaction) test certificate, proving they are Ebola virus
  free.
- All visitors are subject to screening and medical checks.
  Passengers may be quarantined for further assessment. Exempt
  are holders of PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) test
  certificate, proving they are Ebola virus free. 
- Visitors not holding return/onward ticket could be refused
  entry.
 - Exempt are:
vaccination:
Vaccination against yellow fever required if arriving within 6
days after leaving or transiting countries with risk of yellow
fever transmission For details, click here.

Exempt from Yellow Fever vaccination:
- Children under 1 year of age.
- Passengers transiting countries with risk of yellow fever
  transmission provided not leaving the transit areas.
Recommended:
- Vaccination against yellow fever for all passengers visiting
  any area outside the main cities in Suriname.
  Malaria prophylaxis: malaria risk (P. vivax and P.
  falciparum) exists throughout the year in the interior of
  the country beyond the coastal savannah area, with highest
  risk mainly along the eastern border and in goldmining
  areas. In Paramaribo City and the other seven coastal
  districts, transmission risk is low or negligible.
  Recommended prevention in risk areas: C.
